this is a web internal web post from one
of our developers on his internal blog
at Amazon uh at this point we've been
writing tons and tons of C++ code most
of it very tightly coupled and
monolithic uh and it was pretty obvious
that we needed to really commit to
making a change at this point so in 20 5
we came up with a new set of of Design
Concepts that we knew we really wanted
to follow and they're listed up here the
reason I list them is that several of
the earliest developers of AWS came from
the Amazon retail side of the business
and they brought a lot of these lessons
with them as they move to AWS so the
first is decoupling right we want to be
able to innovate various components of
our system independently we want to have
good reuse uh that leads us to pursue
service oriented architectures uh so
that we can come with a a very Loosely
coupled system uh and build it out in
independent parts we want to scale
horizontally and iterate quickly uh Jeff
be is very passionate about keeping the
business moving very fast like a startup
would uh and horizontal scalability
allows us to keep cost down while we're
doing it finally uh we really wanted to
focus on Simplicity so given two
possible ways to solve a problem uh
absent any other considerations choose
the simpler of the two don't over
engineer a lot up front instead build
what your customer wants and as you
learn more about what the customer wants
over time add capability in at that
point don't build it all in from the
beginning so our story will slow down a
little bit here it's 2006 now and uh
2006 is an important year because it's
the year that AWS first launched uh a
couple of their external services in
March of that year S3 uh became
generally available and in Q3 of that
year the public beta of ec2 was launched
and that's where I'm going to focus most
of the rest of the time of this
presentation on is how we started using
these things so the question we faced at
the beginning of 2006 is well there's
really only S3 right so what can you do
with just S3 uh you know we have this
saying at Amazon we'd like to eat our
own dog food and so the goal was to
really start using some of this stuff uh
and there were a number of pretty
obvious internal use cases we had a lot
of NFS servers that we could have uh
migrated to S3 we were using a lot of uh
pretty expensive network attached
storage devices but our flagship product
is really the amazon.com website right
and so we wanted to come up with with a
way to use something that would touch
the website and so the answer was this
um if you would have looked at the
amazon.com website in 2006 on a DVD or a
VHS video page you would have seen this
widget called the theatrical release
information widget basically this is
data that is supplied by the Internet
Movie Database IMDb which is a a company
that's sort of a wholly owned subsidiary
of Amazon and basically it tells you
some information about the movie that
you might be uh looking at here now the
fact that this data was supplied by IMDb
on the amazon.com website and these are
subsidiary companies uh posed some
really unique challenges and to
understand that let's look at how we
were rendering that widget back in 2006
uh pretty basic looking service oriented
architecture here customer comes in from
the left they hit the amazon.com web
server that web server makes a service
call to the IMDb service and that
service is really just sort of a caching
front end for a database the IMDb
database that service returns some raw
data which then gets transformed into
HTML and sent back to the customer now
you know nothing particularly
revolutionary here except that given the
relationship between these two companies
it was causing problems the first thing
is that the release process is coupled
right they're returning raw data that
gets transformed into HTML and the
amazon.com web servers so if they want
to change the way that widget looks they
have to write code that goes on the
amazon.com machines which means they
have to know about our release process
our QA process our test our uh all the
other sort of processes that are in
place on amazon.com additionally
amazon.com has very stringent runtime
latency requirements for any widget that
appears on the website uh and IMDb
wasn't real crazy about meeting these
latency requirements at that
time third is there this also this
problem related to scale right IMDb
Amazon has this seasonal business that
picks up in Q4 and we'll talk a little
bit about that later
uh but IMDb would have to know about
that in order to appropriately scale
their hardware and that's not really
something they should need to know about
they don't they don't really want to
know the nuances of the Amazon business
finally there are service integration
issues uh at this point in time IMDb was
using a different service architecture
than Amazon was so getting the Amazon
client to talk to the IMDb service was a
non-trivial task so the solution that we
came up with uh today almost seems
totally obvious and trivial uh but back
in 2006 we were using lots of RPC
architectures and now rest has sort of
you know uh taken on a new life uh but
basically we decided we're going to use
S3 as a restful service basically so
we'd store raw HTML in S3 and we just
retrieve it and concatenate it into the
amazon.com web pages so to get a feel
for how this works uh here's an after
architecture at the bottom basically the
customer comes in from the left hits the
amazon.com web server that web server
now has a generic component on it that
can go pull something out of an S3
bucket and simply concatenate it into a
web page right just already pre-formed
HTML uh I've drawn the IMDb service here
as a black box because from the
amazon.com perspective it is a black box
right we have no idea how they're
getting their content into S3 and that's
frankly the way it should be right we
want to completely decouple these
businesses uh and as you can see this is
a really generic capability that you can
start applying to lot lots of other
widgets on the website so we thought
that this type of architecture had the
ability to to Really spread throughout
the website and some of the results that
we got from it are well first of all
that it reduced page latency S3 had a
flatter more consistent faster latency
curve than the imbb service did secondly
IMDb no longer had to worry about
scaling right now the number of requests
that we're going to make to that data
store are handled by S3 uh the process
of filling that data store is completely
asynchronous and IMDb can do it at is
based on the rate of change of their
data not the rate of our customer
requests it reduced the web server CPU
utilization because we're no longer
transforming raw service output into
HTML right we're simply concatenating
pre-formed HTML into a web page which is
a very easy operation for a web server
to do uh it improved availability
because we've reduced the number of
dependencies right if you look back at
those diagrams there used to be both an
IMDb service and a database that's two
dependencies either one fails you're in
trouble right we've replaced that with a
single dependency 3 um obviously we
don't want S3 to fail but fewer
dependencies is always good when you're
trying to improve availability of a
system and so this reduces the uh the
number of dependencies and as you start
using this architecture on other widgets
on the website each time now you're
removing at least you know two
dependencies and replacing it with the
one you've already taken on S3 so you're
dramatically improving the availability
of your your site uh it simplifies the
release model because IMDb can fill
their buckets whenever they want at
whatever rate R they want and there's a
really neat thing uh there's a uh it's
getting more talk nowadays called blue
green deployments uh that some of you
may have heard of but basically the
concept is if IMDb wants to change that
widget they can simply fill up a new
bucket with the new version of their
widget right and then we can flip the
website over to using that new bucket if
it turns out there's some problem with
that and and they don't like it we can
always flip back instantly to using the
old bucket it gives you this really
elegant way to deploy change to the
website in a controlled manner with
simple roll back and then finally at the
time we didn't realize this because we
weren't big users of of Ajax in 2006 on
the amazon.com website but having this
pre-formed HTML and S3 set us up
perfectly for a world of Ajax it's just
as easy for a web or for a browser to
concatenate that HTML into a page as it
was the web server and so when we moved
to Ajax it made it super
simple so the question though is of
course that's a very simple use case
what about something more complicated so
the Second Use case I've picked is one
that is a lot more complicated this is a
screenshot of an internal application
that we built called client experience
analytics uh for those of you that may
run websites uh it's always a challenge
to get client side data about the
performance of your web pages and this
is an application we built internally to
do that now up until this point in 2008
we had used external services to do this
the problem with the external Services
one they're really expensive when you
start using them at scale and two
they're black boxes we could never tell
exactly what they were measuring and and
why a page did or didn't get slow or
fast so the problem here is that we
wanted to go build this application from
scratch and we knew that it was going to
have a lot of moving parts right it's
basically a very large workflow system
that's going to allow users to specify
pages to be rendered it's going to
create a whole bunch of clients out in
the world to render those pages and then
aggregate tons of data and fire alarms
and all sorts of things very complicated
system um and it has to run in an
external data center if it ran on the
amazon.com retail Network we wouldn't be
getting true client side data we would
have been getting our own network data
and so we wanted to wanted it to be
external the third thing is we weren't
going to charge for this internally and
in free apps at amazon.com tend to get a
lot of usage if they're any good and so
we knew there would probably be the
likelihood that we'd have to scale this
application up quickly if it took off
internally and finally we were given a
couple months and two people to build
this and so the takeaway is that if you
only have two people in a couple months
